item.title: G7: Rich nations back deal to tax multinationals
item.description: G7 finance ministers have agreed to work together to create a "level playing field" on global taxation.

item.title: Covid in Scotland: Restriction levels ease for millions of Scots
item.description: Many areas of the country go from level two to level one but there are no changes for much of the central belt.

item.title: EuroMillions: Jackpot of more than £111m won by UK ticket holder
item.description: Players are being asked to check to see if they have won the prize - the ninth biggest in lottery history.

item.title: Covid: People in hospital with Indian variant not increasing significantly - NHS boss
item.description: Chris Hopson says vaccines seem to have "broken the chain" between infection and serious illness.

item.title: Kayakers save pair of eagles drowning in Danube river
item.description: Klaudia Kis and Richard Varga made the chance encounter while kayaking up the Danube river.

item.title: United plans supersonic passenger flights by 2029
item.description: The US airline has ordered 15 supersonic passenger jets which could cut travel times in half.

item.title: FBI sought info on who read USA Today news article for case
item.description: The USA Today newspaper is resisting an FBI demand to hand over data on readers of its story.

item.title: US gun laws: Judge overturns California assault weapons ban
item.description: The judge ruled that the law undermined constitutional gun ownership rights.

item.title: Covid Victoria: 'Swab dogs' spread joy in Melbourne lockdown
item.description: Tiffany White runs a popular Instagram account documenting the dogs that visit Covid testing sites.

item.title: Microsoft says error caused 'Tank Man' Bing censorship
item.description: Microsoft's Bing search engine showed no image results for the famous Tiananmen Square protester.

item.title: Elections watchdog admits errors in reporting Tory donations
item.description: The Electoral Commission says it wrongly disclosed the party received money from a defunct firm.

item.title: The Papers: 'Jabs blitz' as infections 'surge'
item.description: Saturday's papers react to a rise in the number of people infected with Covid in the UK.

item.title: Covid in Nepal: Families forced to say goodbye through crematorium gates
item.description: In the last month alone, more than 4,000 people in Nepal have died with Covid-19.

item.title: Coventry City of Culture: Getting ready for the launch event
item.description: Coventry City of Culture: Getting ready for the launch event

item.title: Wallace and Gromit: Comedy duo set for Preston statue
item.description: The much-loved animated characters will be cast in bronze in their creator's birthplace of Preston.

item.title: Week in pictures: 29 May - 4 June 2021
item.description: A selection of powerful images taken around the world this week.

item.title: Cannabis boom: Why Oklahoma is a 'wild wild west'
item.description: The conservative state's hands-off approach has made it the hottest weed market in the US.

item.title: Belgium's Van Ranst: Covid scientist targeted by a far-right sniper
item.description: Many scientists have come under attack in the pandemic, but Marc Van Ranst's family are in a safe house.

item.title: G7 summit: What is it and why is it in Cornwall?
item.description: World leaders will descend on the Cornish coast later this month.

item.title: Early menopause: 'I was grieving that I couldn't have children'
item.description: From hot flushes on dates to feelings of grief, being menopausal at university was tough for Éimi.

item.title: The show highlighting Iran's rich artistic streak
item.description: Its V&A curator hopes it's a way to get visitors to think beyond Tehran's tensions with the west.

item.title: Ceuta and Melilla: Spain's enclaves in North Africa
item.description: Moroccans accuse Spain of colonialism by retaining control of Ceuta and Melilla.

item.title: Mexico mid-terms marred by threats, attacks and killings
item.description: Observers say it has been one of the most violent campaigns, with at least 90 election-related killings.

item.title: Is it the end of an era for LeBron James?
item.description: After LeBron James and the Los Angeles Lakers are knocked out in the first round of this season's NBA play-offs, BBC Sport asks: Is this the end of an era?

item.title: US Women's Open: Mel Reid falls to sixth at halfway, having led after round one
item.description: England's Mel Reid loses her opening round lead at the US Women's Open after carding a two-over 73 on day two.

item.title: Euro 2020: Wales await Red Wall's emotional return for Albania friendly
item.description: Wales' fans, known as the Red Wall, will return for the first time since 2019 for Saturday's friendly with Albania.

item.title: Covid: What do under-30s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: The vaccine rollout is now reaching younger adults. What do they need to know about getting jabbed?

item.title: Covid: What refund rights are there for holidays abroad?
item.description: What rights do you have if your holidays plans or rules change?

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: 'Nepal variant': What's the mutation stopping green list trips to Portugal?
item.description: Ministers have raised concerns over a mutation to the Delta variant first identified in India.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Covid-19 rules in Wales are changing - but for many in Scotland the lifting of lockdown has been "paused".

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: Foreign holidays are now possible, but travellers must follow strict rules on their return.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 38 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid-19: Could a third wave change 21 June plans in England?
item.description: Rising coronavirus cases have called the planned 21 June relaxing of rules in England into question.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Do social distance rules apply after both vaccine jabs?
item.description: Guidance on hugging close friends and family has being relaxed in England and Scotland.

item.title: Travel guide to Spain, Portugal, France and more holiday hotspots
item.description: What you need to know about travelling abroad to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Rules are relaxing, but masks are still needed in some settings - here's where and why.

item.title: Tokyo Olympic Games: When are they and will they go ahead despite Covid?
item.description: The Tokyo Summer Olympics are due to start in July, despite a surge in Covid cases in Japan.

item.title: Covid: How is Europe lifting lockdown restrictions?
item.description: A third Covid wave hit much of Europe hard but now gradually lockdowns are being eased.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: Covid vaccine update: Those that work - and the others on the way
item.description: Covid vaccination campaigns are under way in the UK and across the world.

item.title: Lockdown muscle loss: Five ways to get back in shape
item.description: Lockdown inactivity may have left people with weaker muscles - there are simple solutions.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk of Covid on public transport?
item.description: As UK coronavirus restrictions are relaxed, public transport could become much busier.

item.title: How are eviction rules for renters and landlords changing?
item.description: The eviction ban is ending, but what does that mean?

item.title: Scottish toy designer Amy Corbett built dream career from Lego
item.description: Amy Corbett turned her childhood passion for creating into a design job and a US TV role as a 'brickmaster' judge.

item.title: Covid: Prison officers take dogs to work to cut prisoners' stress
item.description: Prison officers say taking their pets to work helps inmates, as well as reducing tension.

item.title: Sandringham: Norfolk knitter recreates Queen's estate in wool
item.description: Two years of knitting for hours a day results in a woolly tribute to a royal countryside residence.

item.title: Drivers caught littering on M6 made to pick it up
item.description: Footage of drivers littering in an emergency area on the M6 is released as part of a campaign.

item.title: Folly Farm's pensioner sloths move into new retirement home
item.description: Tuppee, 26, and Lightcap, 36 have been well suited to a lazy lockdown, says their sloth keeper.

item.title: The Motherload: How pandemic anger almost destroyed a mums' support group
item.description: Abusive messages from angry mums during lockdown almost caused the founder of The Motherload to close it down.

item.title: The children selling explicit videos on OnlyFans
item.description: British subscription site OnlyFans is failing to prevent underage users from selling and appearing in explicit videos, a BBC investigation has found.

item.title: How Ben Crump became America's go-to police brutality lawyer
item.description: When families lose a loved one in a police shooting, more often than not Ben Crump gets a call. Why is he the go-to man?

item.title: Samantha Azzopardi: Australia's notorious con artist sentenced for child theft
item.description: Authorities are baffled by the "bizarre crime" of a serial con artist who has travelled the world.

item.title: After a 32-year battle for justice, what is Hillsborough's legacy?
item.description: As the collapse of the last criminal trial marks the end of a long legal road, Judith Moritz asks what the legacy of Britain’s worst sports disaster is.
